questionText: What statement is true about the command ipv6 unicast-routing?
comments: This should be placed into Chapter 30

answerChoices.Text: This command is required for the assignment of IPv6 addresses to interfaces.
This command is required for the dynamic assignment of IPv6 addresses to interfaces.
This command is required for the operation of IPv6 routing on the device.
This command has been deprecated and is no longer recommended.

questionText: A company uses global unicast addresses (GUAs) for hosts. For a few router functions, they also use IPv6 anycast addresses. Which answer best describes the IPv6 anycast address to use?
explanation:
With IPv6 anycast, multiple routers configure the same IPv6 unicast address as an interface address. Each router advertises a route for that address. For any endpoints that attempt to send a packet to that address, the routers forward the packet based on the best route. As a result, the packet arrives at one of the routers that implement the anycast address. With this model, you can implement services so that the nearest router supplies the service without the user of the service being aware of multiple routers providing the service.

IPv6 does not use a reserved address range, as suggested in two answers. Instead, it uses any unicast address you might otherwise use in the network but one not in any deployed subnet. As for the other incorrect answer, the router does not calculate the anycast address from a MAC address.

answerChoices.Text: A GUA address from the block used by the company
The reserved anycast address range: FA00::/7
The reserved anycast address range: FC00::/7
A number calculated by the router from its interface MAC address

questionText:
R1#show ipv6 int fa 0/0
FastEthernet0/0 is up, line protocol is up
  IPv6 is enabled, link-local address is FE80::200:11FF:FE11:1111
  No Virtual link-local address(es):
  Global unicast address(es):
    2001:12:32::1, subnet is 2001:12:32::/64
  Joined group address(es):
    FF02::1
    FF02::2
    FF02::5
    FF02::6
    FF02::9
    FF02::A
    FF02::1:FF00:1
    FF02::1:FF11:1111
  MTU is 1500 bytes
  ICMP error messages limited to one every 100 milliseconds
  ICMP redirects are enabled
  ICMP unreachables are sent
  ND DAD is enabled, number of DAD attempts: 1
  ND reachable time is 30000 milliseconds (using 42973)
  ND advertised reachable time is 0 (unspecified)
  ND advertised retransmit interval is 0 (unspecified)
  ND router advertisements are sent every 200 seconds
  ND router advertisements live for 1800 seconds
  ND advertised default router preference is Medium
  Hosts use stateless autoconfig for addresses.
R1#


	What can be determined based on the output provided?
explanation:
IPv6 devices join multicast groups depending on which multicast traffic they want to process. OSPF are the multicast groups ending in 5 and 6. EIGRP is the group ending in A, and RIPng is the group ending in 9.

	The router is enabled for IPv6 unicast routing because it has joined the group ending in 2. The link-local address very well could be using the defaults, if the MAC address is 0000.1111.1111 The output shows that DAD, duplicate address detection, is on.
comments:
ICND2-19-03

--

This should be in Chapter 30`

answerChoices.Text: The router is running IPv6 EIGRP.
The router is not enabled for IPv6 unicast routing.
The link-local address is not using the default modified EUI-64 format.
The interface will not participate in duplicate address detection.

questionText:
Based on the configuration provided below, what would be the assigned link local address?

interface FastEthernet0/0
  mac-address 0000.5B2D.003A
  ipv6 address 2000:AB83:00FB:1DAE::/64 eui-64
explanation: The EUI-64 process involves the creation of a 64-bit interface ID using the interface’s MAC address. First, the address is split into two 24-bit pieces (0000.5B and 2D.003A), then the string FFFE is inserted into the middle of them (0000.5BFF:FE2D.003A), and then the seventh high-order bit (from the left) is flipped (0 > 1 or 1 > 0), giving a final 64-bit result of 0200.5BFF:FE2D.003A. This host ID is then appended onto the link local prefix of FE80::/10, resulting in the FE80::200:5BFF:FE2D:3A abbreviated IPv6 address.

questionText: Based on the IPv6 solicited multicast address of FF02::1:FFE0:8, which of the global unicast addresses could be configured?
explanation: The solicited-node multicast address is used to send traffic to a limited subnet of local devices. One common user is the IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) process. The RFC specifies that the first 104 bits of the address are always FF02:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001:FF, with the last 24 bits coming from a device’s IPv6 address. This means that for a device to use the FF02::1:FFE0:8 solicited-node multicast address, the last 24 bits (6 hex digits) of the configured address must be E0.0008. The only answer matching this is the 2500:AB83:EBAC:9134:C801:1AFF:FEE0:0008 address.

questionText:
A router, R1, does not have IPv6 unicast routing enabled. An engineer configures the commands listed below. What addresses do you expect to see listed by the show ipv6 interface brief command?


R1(config-if)# mac-address 0000.1111.1111
R1(config-if)# ipv6 enable
explanation:
First, note that the router accepts the ipv6 enable interface subcommand regardless of whether the router has enabled IPv6 routing. That fact rules out one answer as incorrect.

The other answers list variations of possible Link-Local Addresses (LLAs) that router R1 might create dynamically based on the configured values. The one correct answer lists the correct LLA. It begins with FE80 and three quartets of 0000. It shows the separated values of 000011 and 111111 from the MAC address. And it shows the effect of inverting the seventh bit of the MAC address, so the first six hex digits of the MAC address become 020011. Finally, it shows FFFE in the middle of the interface ID. All those facts combine to support FE80::200:11FF:FE11:1111 as the correct LLA.

The other incorrect answers have these issues:


	One lists the same address but in unabbreviated form. The question asked for the abbreviated address.
	One lists the same address without inverting the seventh bit of the MAC address.
	One lists the correct value except for using FF instead of FE as the first two digits.
comments:
ICND2-19-01

--

This should be in Chapter 30

answerChoices.Text: None, because IPv6 routing is not enabled

questionText: Based on the exhibit, which two solicited-node multicast addresses will the router create?
explanation:
The router will create a solicited-node multicast address for every unicast address on its interface.

	The abbreviation used to create these addresses is FF02::1:FF_ _:_ _ _ _ (the last 24 bits of the unicast address). Therefore, FF02::1:FF00:1 and

	FF02::1:FFAB:ABAB will be the two solicited-node multicast addresses created.

questionText:
Based on the following configuration, what would be the assigned global unicast address?


interface fastEthernet0/0 
  mac-address 0200.8395.2614 
  ipv6 address 2500:A4B3:ED81:ACEB::/64 eui-64
explanation: The EUI-64 process involves the creation of a 64-bit interface ID using the interface’s MAC address. First, the address is split into two 24-bit pieces (0200.83 and 95.2614); then the string FFFE is inserted into the middle of them (0200.83FF:FE95.2614), and then the seventh high-order bit (from the left) is flipped (0 > 1 or 1 > 0), giving a final 64-bit result of 0000.83FF.FE95.2614. This host ID is then appended onto the configured IPv6 prefix, giving a final IPv6 address of 2500:A4B3:ED81:ACEB:0000:83FF:FE95:2614.

questionText: Given the global unicast address of  2000:B71A:8560:AB73:816A:BE81:AB71:FF01, what would the solicited-node multicast address be?
explanation: The solicited-node multicast address is used to send traffic to a limited subnet of local devices. One common use is the IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) process. The RFC specifies that the first 104 bits of the address are always FF02:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001:FF, with the last 24 bits coming from a device’s IPv6 address. This means that a device configured with the 2000:B71A:8560:AB73:816A:BE81:AB71:FF01 IPv6 address would have a solicited-node multicast address of FF02::1:FF71:FF01.

questionText:
Router R1’s Fa0/0 interface was up and working, and was then configured as follows:

R1(config)# interface fa0/0
R1(config-if)# mac-address 0011.2233.4455
R1(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:1234::1/64

	Which IPv6 unicast addresses would now be included in the output of the command show ipv6 interface fa0/0 on R1?
explanation:
The global unicast address of 2001:1234::1 would be exactly as configured. The link-local address would be FE80::211:22FF:FE33:4455, using the modified EUI-64 format, with the 7th bit of the MAC address inverted.

	Regarding the other answers, FE80::11:22FF:FE33:4455 doesn’t have the 7th bit from the MAC address inverted. The other global address of 2001:1234::211:22FF:FE33:4455 uses the EUI 64 format, and in the output of the configuration, we specified the whole IP without the modified EUI-64 option for the host ID. Two of the addresses beginning with FF are multicast groups that were joined (solicited node multicast groups, based on the two IP addresses in use by the router).
comments:
ICND2-19-IPv6-a

--

This should be in Chapter 30

questionText: Examine the configuration commands in the exhibit. Which answer best describes what the commands configure?
explanation:
The ipv6 address command shows a mask of /64 but no eui-64 parameter to follow. As a result, the command defines an entire IPv6 address. From the beginning digit of 2, you can tell that the address comes from the global unicast range.

For the incorrect answers, the ipv6 address command would need the eui-64 keyword to dynamically cause the router to form the interface ID portion of the address. From the address value's first digit (2), you know that the address does not come from the link-local or multicast address ranges, both of which begin with F.

answerChoices.Text: A global unicast address with the entire address specified
A global unicast address with the interface ID determined dynamically

questionText: Refer to the diagram; what type of IPv6 message would PC1 use to find the MAC address of R1?
explanation:
When an IPv6 device needs to find the MAC address of a local device based on that device's IPv6 address (like ARP with IPv4), it uses the Neighbor Solicitation (NS) message. The device using that IPv6 address then returns (assuming it exists on the local network) a Neighbor Advertisement (NA) message. So in this question, an NA and NS message would flow, but the NS message is the message sent by PC1 to request R1's MAC address.

	For the other two incorrect answers, host PC1 may need use a Router Solicitation (RS) message to request each router on the LAN to announce itself along with its IPv6 addresses and known IPv6 prefixes. Router R1 would then reply with an Router Advertisement (RA) message listing that information. However, the RA message lists IPv6 addressing and prefix information, but not MAC address information, which is what the question mentions.

questionText: PC1 and PC2 reside on the same VLAN. Both hosts use IPv6. When PC1 pings PC2’s IPv6 address, PC1 does not know PC2’s MAC address. How does PC1 learn PC2’s MAC address?
explanation: Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) acts as a replacement for several IPv4  protocols, including ARP, as well as providing several new functions  for IPv6. ARP does not exist in IPv6.
comments:
CD-I2-3-53-003-1

 

--

questionText: Which of the following are used in a conventional IPv6 DHCP message exchange?
explanation:
In DHCP for IPv6, the four principal messages are Solicit, Advertise, Request, and Reply.

In DHCP for IPv4, the message types include Discover, Offer, Request, and ACK/NAK. Due to the question being for IPv6 DHCP, the Discover, Offer, and Acknowledgment are not correct answers. Both IPv6 and IPv4 DHCP include a “Request” message.

questionText:
The exhibit lists output from the netsh interface ipv6 show address command on a Windows host. Note that the three addresses end with values 1, 2, and 3. Which answers describe how this host will use the three addresses shown? (Choose two answers.)


C:\Users\Wendell> netsh interface ipv6 show address

Interface 2: Ethernet

Addr Type  DAD State   Valid Life Pref. Life Address
---------  ----------- ---------- ---------- ------------------------
Temporary  Preferred  6d23h57m58s   23h49m3s 2001:db8:1111:1:c1cd:7a44:45a5:58f1
Public     Preferred     infinite   infinite 2001:db8:1111:1:f1f5:5cbb:f395:6c52
Other      Preferred     infinite   infinite fe80::3%2
explanation:
The answers list two sets of three related concepts – one about inbound connections and another about outbound. Each set of three appears to allow for only one of the three to be selected.

The command output shows information consistent with using SLAAC on a Windows host.   It lists an address type with values of temporary and public, which identifies which addresses the host uses for outbound (temporary) and inbound (public) connections. Also, the public address row shows an infinite valid lifetime, which makes sense for an address used for inbound connections, as it will also likely be added permanently to your DNS records. The temporary row shows a preferred lifetime – the time the host prefers to use this host for new outgoing connections – of a little under one day.

The host uses address 2 (the public address) for inbound connections, not the other two. The host uses address 1 (the temporary address) for the outbound connections. The host does not use address 3, a link-local address, for any user application traffic but instead for overhead protocols that remain on the local link.

answerChoices.Text: It uses the address ending in 1 for new inbound connections.
It uses the address ending in 2 for new inbound connections.
It uses the address ending in 3 for new inbound connections.
It uses the address ending in 1 for new outbound connections.
It uses the address ending in 2 for new outbound connections.
It uses the address ending in 3 for new outbound connections.

questionText: Refer to the diagram and assume that R1 was configured correctly to perform IPv6 prefix advertisement and PC1 was configured to use SLAAC to form its IPv6 address. Which IPv6 message would R1 use to advertise its prefix to PC1?
explanation:
When a router is configured to support IPv6 routing (ipv6 unicast-routing), it supports IPv6 prefix advertisements. The router sends these prefixes in a Router Advertisement (RA) message; they are unsolicited on configured intervals and solicited via Router Solicitation (RS) messages sent by the SLAAC client.

For the NA and NS incorrect answers, please remember that the NDP NA and NS messages define how hosts learn the MAC addresses used by other hosts in the same IPv5 subnet. For instance, the PC could use a Neighbor Solicitation (NS) message to ask the router to supply its MAC address, with the router providing that information in a Neighbor Advertisement (NA) message.

questionText: Refer to the diagram and assume that R1 was configured correctly to perform IPv6 prefix advertisement and PC1 was configured to use SLAAC to form its IPv6 address. Which IPv6 message would R1 use to advertise its prefix to PC1?
explanation: When a router is configured to support IPv6 routing (ipv6 unicast-routing), it supports IPv6 prefix advertisements. The router sends these prefixes in a Router Advertisement (RA) message; they are sent unsolicited on configured intervals and solicited via Router Solicitation (RS) messages sent by the SLAAC client.

questionText: Which of the following are core functions of the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP)?
explanation:
SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) uses NDP messages so that hosts learn the IPv6 prefixes on the link from any routers connected to the link. Hosts ask for this information using Router Solicitation (RS) messages, with routers replying with Router Advertisement (RA) messages – both part of NDP. The RA messages can supply information such as:


	IPv6 prefixes on the link
	Router IPv6 addresses on the link
	A list of DNS servers


Additionally, NDP replaces the functions done by ARP in IPv4. It uses Neighbor Solicitation (NS) and Neighbor Advertisement (NA) messages so any IPv6 host can request and learn the MAC address used by other online IPv6 endpoints.

Information about routes for prefixes not located on the same link requires other tools, like dynamic routing protocols used on routers. Hosts do not usually need a dynamic process to learn specific routes for IPv6 subnets located beyond the local link. Instead, hosts rely on their default router setting as learned from routers via the NDP RA messages

questionText: An IPv6 host is using stateless address autoconfiguration and EUI-64 to dynamically learn its global unicast IPv6 address. The host’s MAC address is 0000.1111.1111. The only router attached to the same LAN has an IPv6 global unicast prefix of 2000:1234:5678:1234::/64. Which of the following are true about this host’s global unicast IPv6 address?
explanation: When using stateless autoconfiguration, a host learns of prefixes using NDP—specifically, NDP router solicitation (RS) and router advertisement (RA) messages. The host then creates the last 64 bits of the address using EUI-64 rules by splitting its 6-byte MAC address in half and adding hex FFFE (2 bytes) to the middle. EUI-64 also calls for flipping the seventh bit in the MAC address. In this case, hex 00 (the first byte) represents 00000000; inverting the 7th bit gives you 00000010, with the first two hex digits will be 02.

answerChoices.Text: The host will learn about prefix 2000:1234:5678:1234::/64 using DHCP.
The host will learn about prefix 2000:1234:5678:1234::/64 using Neighbor Discovery Protocol.
The host will use 0200:1111:1111 as the last 3 quartets of its IPv6 address.
The host will use 0200:11FF:FE11:1111 as the last 4 quartets of its IPv6 address.

questionText:
The exhibit lists output from the traceroute6 command on Linux host A in the figure. Which answer correctly identifies the IPv6 address and interface combinations on the routers that would result in the output in the exhibit? (Choose two answers.)


Linux_A:$ traceroute6 2001:db8:1111:2::b
traceroute to 2001:db8:1111:2::b (2001:db8:1111:2::b) from 2001:db8:1111:1::a,
   30 hops max, 24 byte packets
1  2001:db8:1111:1::1 (2001:db8:1111:1::1)  0.794 ms  0.648 ms  0.604 ms
2  2001:db8:1111:1222::1 (2001:db8:1111:1222::1)  1.6 ms  1.49 ms  1.54 ms
3  2001:db8:1111:2::b (2001:db8:1111:2::b)  2.03 ms  1.911 ms  1.89 ms
explanation:
IPv6 traceroute commands list router interfaces' routable unicast addresses (global unicast or unique local). The first address should be the unicast address of the interface used as the host's default router. The additional lines should list other routers' unicast addresses. If the command succeeds, the final line lists the address in the command. In this case, that address refers to host B's address. 

In this case, the addresses in the output should list the addresses associated with these interfaces in this sequence. Combining the analysis of the interfaces with the three addresses listed on the three key output lines from the traceroute6 command, the following list details which interface uses which address:


	R1’s G0/0/0 interface (2001:db8:1111:1::1)
	R2’s G0/0/0 interface (2001:db8:1111:1222::1)
	Host B (2001:db8:1111:2::b)


The answers mention only router interfaces. The two correct answers list the router interface and address combinations from the first two entries above.

questionText: When a device sends a Router Solicitation (RS) NDP packet, looking for a new local IPv6 router, which destination address would be involved in this request?
explanation:
When an IPv6 device sends an RS, the destination address will be the “all routers” multicast address of FF02::2.

FF02::1 is the all nodes multicast address and isn’t used as the destination address in an RS message. Neither the unicast nor Solicited Node Multicast address of the router is used as a destination address for a device sending an RS message looking for new IPv6 routers. IPv6 doesn’t use a “broadcast” address.

answerChoices.Text: The unicast address of a router
The solicited node multicast address of a router

questionText: Some IPv6 hosts use SLAAC and RDNSS to learn their IPv6 address and related IPv6 settings. Which answers identify how a host learns a particular IPv6 setting? (Choose three answers.)
explanation:
The RDNSS acronym refers to RA-based DNS Server configuration. Knowing that fact alone should identify one correct and incorrect answer: The host learns the DNS server list from the NDP RA message. RDNSS replaces stateless DHCP for the same purpose, a tool that stores the list of DNS servers on a DHCP server and uses DHCP messages to inform the host.

The host learns the other settings using typical SLAAC processes. When using SLAAC, the host finds its address prefix from the NDP RA message that one or more routers on the subnet send. The RA identifies the prefixes that exist on the subnet. From that, the host self-assigns a unicast address using that prefix and then chooses an interface ID (IID). Most host operating systems use a randomized process to select the IID rather than using EUI-64.

A SLAAC host learns its default router setting from the router itself. The router sends an NDP RA message which includes the router's IPv6 address (an LLA) that hosts should use as their default router setting. The host does not need to use any information stored on the DHCP server.

answerChoices.Text: Its address prefix from an NDP RA message.
Its address prefix from a DHCPv6 message.
Its default router address from an NDP RA message.
Its default router address from a DHCPv6 message.
Its DNS server list from an NDP RA message.
Its DNS server list from a DHCPv6 message.

questionText: When a device sends a Router Solicitation (RS) NDP packet, looking for a new local IPv6 router, which destination address would be involved in this request?
explanation:
When an IPv6 device sends an RS, the destination address will be the “all routers” multicast address of FF02::2.

	FF02::1 is the all nodes multicast address and isn’t used as the destination address in an RS message. Neither the unicast nor Solicited Node Multicast address of the router is used as a destination address for a device sending an RS message looking for new IPv6 routers. IPv6 doesn’t use a “broadcast” address.

answerChoices.Text: The unicast address of a router
The solicited node multicast address of a router

questionText: An IPv6 host learns its IPv6 configuration using SLAAC. Which answers correctly describe the meaning of the IPv6 address attributes applied to the addresses created for the host using SLAAC?
explanation:
Hosts that use SLAAC and other processes to find IPv6 addresses to use temporarily may use calendared address attributes. The host uses calendared addresses for TCP and UDP flows the host initiates. For connections initiated into the host, the host would typically use a permanent address rather than a temporary one (a fact confirming one answer as incorrect.)

The three address attributes related to the calendared temporary addresses, used for flows initiated by the host, include:

Preferred: Use to initiate all new connections at this time, typically with a single preferred address on an interface at any instant.

Valid: Formerly-preferred addresses which can continue to send packets over existing flows. However, the host does not create new flows using a valid address.

Deprecated: Formerly valid addresses that the host no longer uses. No packet flow occurs with addresses with this attribute.

The facts in the above list confirm the reasoning behind the two correct answers and rule out the remaining incorrect answers.

answerChoices.Text: It uses a valid address to initiate new TCP and UDP flows
It can continue using a deprecated address to send data over existing TCP and UDP flows.
It uses a preferred address to initiate new TCP and UDP flows.
It can continue using a valid address to send data over existing TCP and UDP flows.
It uses a preferred address to accept new incoming connections from other hosts.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would correctly route traffic destined for the 8163:bc23:4632:ac23::/64 network using the fe80::1234:7484:26b4:2362 next hop address out the GigabitEthernet0/1 interface?
explanation:
The correct syntax for an IPv6 static route to an interface is ipv6 route prefix/prefix-length interface link-local-next-hop. In this case, the correct command would be ipv6 route 8163:bc23:4632:ac23::/64 Gi0/1 fe80::1234:7484:26b4:2362.

	One incorrect answer matches the correct answer exactly, other than omitting the Gi0/1 parameter. The command should include the outgoing interface id because it also uses a next-hop link-local address.

	Two incorrect answers have incorrect syntax. One begins with ip route v6, an invalid sequence of command and parameters. The other shows the destination subnet value ending with ":/64" - that is, it does not end with "::/64" - so it neither defines an IPv6 subnet nor a valid IPv6 address.

questionText: Refer to the diagram. An engineer is tasked with configuring a floating static route on R1. The faster path to the 3000::/64 network should be prioritized over the other using an administrative distance of 10 versus an administrative distance of 20 for the slower path. Which command would correctly configure the lower priority route using an IPv6 next-hop address?
explanation: A floating static route uses the same format as all IPv6 static routes but explicitly adds an administrative distance. In this case, the command to configure would be ipv6 route 3000::/64 2000::2 10. The second command would be ipv6 route 3000::/64 2001::2 20. Note, however, that the interface being used for the primary route must go down in order for the second route to be inserted into the routing table.

questionText: The answers show candidate ipv6 route global commands for router R1 referencing the IPv6 subnet on the right side of the figure. Assume all links are up and working with the addresses shown in the figure. Which answer lists a command that configures a working route on router R1? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
IOS may reject an ipv6 route command when configured. It may accept the command, placing it into the configuration, but only add a route to the IPv6 routing table per that configuration under certain conditions. Sometimes, the route placed into the routing table may not be useful for forwarding IPv6 packets. Working through the commands in the various answers:

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/1 command: IOS accepts the command, adds it to the configuration, and adds a route to the routing table. However, the route does not function nor attempt to forward packets to R2 as the next-hop router.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 fe80::2 command: IOS rejects the command. IOS logic allows it to recognize the next-hop address as an LLA. IOS also requires an outgoing interface parameter on the command if referring to an LLA as the next-hop address.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 2001:db8:1:12::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. The route should work because IOS should have a route that matches the next-hop address 2001:db8:1:12::2, as it is an address in the subnet between the two routers. 

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/1 fe80::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. The command lists the correct outgoing interface (R1's G0/0/1) and the LLA that router R2 uses on the link between R1 and R2 (fe80::2), so the route should work to forward packets to router R2 next.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/0 2001:db8:1:12::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. However, the route refers to R1's G0/0/0 as the outgoing interface, which is not the correct interface out which to forward packets for this route. As a result, this route will appear in the routing table but not be useful in forwarding packets.

As noted in the various explanations, two answers in this scenario result in a working route added to the routing table.

questionText: What value is used in an IPv6 route that indicates all traffic and is used in default routes?
explanation: When an IPv6 static route is configured, the ::/0 value indicates an all traffic match (similar to the way 0.0.0.0 is used with IPv4).

questionText: Examine the output shown in the exhibit. What is true about the number 1 shown in brackets?
explanation: The only brackets show "[1/0]". The number 1 indicates the administrative distance for the entry. The other number number (0 in this case) indicates the metric. One potential metric is hop count, and this is also incorrect. Finally, this number does not dictate the order for analysis in routing decisions. This logic is built in to the router and cannot be directly manipulated.
comments: this should be placed into Chapter 32

answerChoices.Text: It is the order of analysis for a routing decision.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would correctly route traffic destined for the 2300:0:2463:114:2573:bc12:aec2:1/64 network using a next-hop address of 3000:2636:2f42:ea36::5425:1?
explanation: The correct syntax for an IPv6 static route to an interface is ipv6 route prefix/prefix-length next-hop. In this case, the correct command would be ipv6 route 2300:0:2463:114::/64 3000:2636:2f42:ea36::5425:1.

questionText: Refer to the diagram. An engineer is tasked with configuring a floating static route on R1. The faster path toward the 3000::/64 network should be prioritized over the other using an administrative distance of 10 versus an administrative distance of 20 for the slower path. Which command would correctly configure the higher priority route using an IPv6 next-hop address?
explanation: A floating static route uses the same format as all IPv6 static routes but explicitly adds an administrative distance. In this case, the command to configure would be ipv6 route 3000::/64 2000::2 10. The second command would be ipv6 route 3000::/64 2001::2 20. Note, however, that the interface being used for the primary route must go down in order for the second route to be inserted into the routing table.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; what is the name of the protocol that would be used between R1 and the ISP router so that R1 would dynamically learn a prefix and calculate an IPv6 address to use?
explanation: The Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) is used for a number of different tasks; one of these is that it allows a host device to solicit a router for the local IPv6 prefix (using a Router Solicitation [RS]) and a router to advertise a link prefix (using a Router Advertisement [RA]). The host device will then use this learned prefix and a calculated host-ID (EUI-64) to form a complete IPv6 address to use on a link. The host can also be configured to automatically use this advertising router IPv6 address as the next hop of a default route.

questionText: The answers show candidate ipv6 route global commands for router R1 referencing the IPv6 subnet on the right side of the figure. Assume all links are up and working with the addresses shown in the figure and that router R2 already has working static routes. Which answers list a command that would result in a static route appearing in R1's IPv6 routing table, but R1 cannot use that route to forward packets successfully? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
IOS may reject an ipv6 route command when configured. It may accept the command, placing it into the configuration, but only add a route to the IPv6 routing table per that configuration under certain conditions. Sometimes, the route placed into the routing table may not be useful for forwarding IPv6 packets. Working through the commands in the various answers:

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/1 command: IOS accepts the command, adds it to the configuration, and adds a route to the routing table. However, the route does not function nor attempt to forward packets to R2 as the next-hop router.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 fe80::2 command: IOS rejects the configuration command. IOS logic allows it to recognize the next-hop address as an LLA. IOS also requires an outgoing interface parameter on the command if referring to an LLA as the next-hop address.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 2001:db8:1:12::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. The route should work because IOS should have a route that matches the next-hop address 2001:db8:1:12::2, as it is an address in the subnet between the two routers. 

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/1 fe80::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. The command lists the correct outgoing interface (R1's G0/0/1) and the LLA that router R2 uses on the link between R1 and R2 (fe80::2), so the route should work to forward packets to router R2 next.

The ipv6 route 2001:db8:1:2::/64 g0/0/0 2001:db8:1:12::2 command: IOS accepts the command, placing it in the configuration. IOS places the route in the IPv6 routing table. However, the route refers to R1's G0/0/0 as the outgoing interface, which is not the correct interface out which to forward packets for this route. As a result, this route will appear in the routing table but not be useful in forwarding packets.

As noted in the various explanations, two answers in this scenario result in a non-working route added to the routing table.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would correctly route traffic destined for the 2300:1451:2463:242d:e3ab:35e4:1563:0001/64 network out the GigabitEthernet0/1 interface?
explanation: The correct syntax for an IPv6 static route to an interface is ipv6 route prefix/prefix-length interface. In this case, the correct command would be ipv6 route 2300:1451:2463:242d::/64 Gi0/1.

questionText: Which network does the IP address 192.168.4.38/27 belong to?
explanation: The network 192.168.4.32/27 has a valid IP address range of 192.168.4.33 to 192.168.4.62. The /27 CIDR notation, or 255.255.255.224 dotted-decimal notation (DDN), defines networks in multiples of 32. Therefore, the address 192.168.4.28/27 is part of the 192.168.4.32/27 network. All of the other options are incorrect.

questionText: What are stateless DHCPv6 servers used for?
explanation: Stateless DHCPv6 servers are used to configure DHCP options only. The one option that all clients need is the DNS server. The default gateway and the IPv6 address are configured via the Router Solicitation (RS) and Router Advertisement (RA) packets when a client starts up in the network. The IPv6 prefix length is fixed to a 64-bit prefix.

questionText: Which mechanism in IPv6 allows for SLAAC to avoid duplicating an IPv6 address?
explanation: Duplicate Address Detection (DAD) uses Neighbor Solicitation and Neighbor Advertisement messages to avoid duplicate addresses when SLAAC is being used. Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) is a protocol that is used to discover neighboring devices in an IPv6 network for layer 2 addressing. Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) is an IPv6 method used to assign the 64-bit network ID to a host. ARPv6 is not a valid protocol; the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) in IPv4 has been replaced with NDP in IPv6.

questionText: Which term best describes the IPv6 address of 2202:0ff8:0002:2344:3533:8eff:fe22:ae4c?
explanation: The IPv6 address 2202:0ff8:0002:2344:3533:8eff:fe22:ae4c is an EUI-64 generated address. The host portion of the address is 3533:8eff:fe22:ae4c; the fffe in the middle of it indicates that the address was generated from the MAC address. The MAC address of this host would be 37-33-8e-02-ae-4c. When EUI-64 is used, an ffee is placed in the middle of the MAC address, and then the 7th bit from the left is flipped. This changes the first two hex digits of the MAC address from 35 to 37. Multicast addresses will always start with ff00. Anycast addresses are not visibly different because they are normal addresses with special regional routing statements that direct communications to the closest server. Link-local addresses will always start with fe80.

questionText: You want all guests to register for wireless Internet access before granting them access. What should you implement?
explanation: A captive portal will allow you to require all guests to register for wireless Internet access before granting them access. When they connect to the Service Set Identifier (SSID), they will be presented with the captive portal web page. An AAA server is required if you have a list of already established users and want to authenticate them via the AAA server. An extended service set (ESS) is two or more access points covering a common SSID or serving multiple SSIDs. Radio resource management (RRM) is a service on the wireless LAN controller (WLC) that adjusts the radio output and channels used by an ESS.

questionText: Which command will allow you to verify the IPv6 addresses configured on a router?
explanation: The command show ipv6 interfaces brief will show all of the IPv6 addresses configured for each of the interfaces on the router. The commands show ipv6, show ip interfaces brief, and show ipv6 brief are incorrect.

questionText: Which command will show you the IPv6 routes in the route table?
explanation: The command show ipv6 route will display only the entries in the route table for IPv6. The command show ip route will only display the entries in the route table for IPv4. The commands show ipv6 route summary and show ipv6 route brief are incorrect.

questionText: In the following figure, which route statement will need to be added to the routers to allow routing between the networks?
explanation: You will need two route statements, one on each router. Each route should point to the far side network through the serial interface. Since the IP address is an IPv6 address, the easier way to configure the routes is to direct the packets to the exit interface of Serial 0/3/0. All of the other options are incorrect because the commands specify either the wrong protocol or the wrong routes.

answerChoices.Text:
RouterA(config)#ip route 2001:db8:1000/64 serial 0/3/0
RouterB(config)#ip route 2001:db8:2000/64 serial 0/3/0

RouterA(config)#ip route 2001:db8:2000::/64 serial 0/3/0
RouterB(config)#ip route 2001:db8:1000::/64 serial 0/3/0

RouterA(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:2000::/64 serial 0/3/0
RouterB(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:1000::/64 serial 0/3/0

RouterA(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:2000::/64 2001:db8:1500::/64 eui-64
RouterB(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:1000::/64 2001:db8:1500::/64 eui-64

questionText: Which command will only show you all of the directly connected routes for IPv6?
explanation: The command show ipv6 route connected will display only the directly connected routes on the router. The commands show ipv6 interface summary, show ipv6 interface brief, and show ipv6 summary are incorrect.

questionText: In the following figure, you need to configure Router B so that hosts on Network B can reach the Internet. Which statement on Router B will allow hosts to reach the Internet?
explanation: The route statement ipv6 route ::/0 serial 0/3/0 will route any network that is unknown by Router B to Router A via the exit interface of Serial 0/3/0. The command ipv6 route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 serial 0/3/0 is incorrect because it mixes IPv4-style IP addresses and the ipv6 route command. The commands ipv6 route 2002:ea34:4520:3412::/64 serial 0/3/0 and ipv6 route ::/0 2001:db8:1500::/64 eui are incorrect.

questionText: In the following figure, which route statement will need to be added to the routers to allow routing between the networks?
explanation: You will need two route statements, one on each router. Each route points to the far side network through the gateway in the ff80::/64 network. Router A has a gateway of ff80::ff:f200:2/64 to the 2001:db8:4:/64 network, and Router B has a gateway of ff80::ff:f200:1/64 to the 2001:db8:400/64 network. All other options are incorrect because the commands specify either the wrong protocol or the wrong routes.

answerChoices.Text:
RouterA(config)#ip route 2001:db8:4/64 ff80::ff:f200:2
RouterB(config)#ip route 2001:db8:400/64 ff80::ff:f200:1

RouterA(config)#ip route 2001:db8:400::/64 serial 0/3/0
RouterB(config)#ip route 2001:db8:4::/64 serial 0/3/0

RouterA(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:400::/64 serial 0/3/0
RouterB(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:4::/64 serial 0/3/0

RouterA(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:4/64 ff80::ff:f200:2
RouterB(config)#ipv6 route 2001:db8:400/64 ff80::ff:f200:1

questionText: Which is an advantage to using Port Address Translation?
explanation: The flexibility of Internet connections is usually a driving factor for PAT (NAT Overloading). Memory is significantly higher with PAT, since the source and destination port numbers must be recorded in the NAT table. There is no effect on packet loss, and jitter is marginally affected. Memory usage is actually higher than with other types of NAT because it must account for ports in the NAT table.

answerChoices.Text: Lower memory usage than other NAT types

questionText: Which command would you configure on the private network interface for NAT?
explanation: The command to configure the private side of the network interface for NAT is ip nat inside. This command is configured on the interface in which you want to define it as the “inside” of your network. The configuration of the command ip nat outside is incorrect. The commands ip nat inside gi0/0 and ip nat private are incorrect.

questionText: Why is time synchronization important for routers and switches?
explanation: Time synchronization is important for logging accuracy. Serial communication frame alignment is timed via clocking and packet queues are timed by how fast they can respond. The serialized communication for frame alignment comes from the DCE side of the link, which provides clocking signals. Time synchronization has no effect on quality of service queuing or the delivery of packets via timed queues.

answerChoices.Text: It is important for serialized communication frame alignment.
It is important for quality of service queuing.
It is important for logging accuracy.
It helps delivery of packets via timed queues.

questionText: Which statement describes FQDNs?
explanation: Fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) are significant from right to left, starting with a period to signify the root. The period is normally not visible on the FQDN, but it is processed as the root lookup. A DNS server will not always process the entire FQDN if there is a cached entry for the resource record requested. FQDNs are not always registered with a registrar because organizations used them for authentication and internal purposes. FQDNs are resolved from right to left starting with the root, not left to right.

answerChoices.Text: A DNS server always processes the entire FQDN.
FQDNs are always registered with a registrar.
FQDNs are significant from left to right, starting with a period for the root.
FQDNs are significant from right to left, starting with a period for the root.

questionText: Which protocol and port number does SNMP use for polling from the NMS?
explanation: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) uses UDP port 161 for communication from an SNMP network management station to a network device for information requests. SNMP uses UDP and TCP port 162 for traps and not polling. Syslog uses UDP and TCP port 514 for sending log entries.

questionText: Which command will allow you to verify the syslog server set for logging and the logging level set?
explanation: The command show logging will display the configured syslog server and the current severity level for logs to be sent to the syslog server. The commands show syslog, show log-server, and show ip logging are incorrect.

questionText: Which command will allow you to verify the IP addresses assigned to a router’s interface?
explanation: The command show ip interface will display the IP addresses configured on the router’s interfaces. It will detail which are static and which have been allocated through DHCP. The command show ip dhcp bindings is incorrect because it will show the internal table for the local DHCP server. The commands show ip lease and show ip dhcp lease are incorrect.

questionText: Where should QoS marking be performed?
explanation: QoS marking should always be performed closest to the source of the traffic. All switches and routers in the network should be configured to properly prioritize markings of traffic in queues. If it is performed closest to the Internet router, you may not get any effectiveness from the configuration because Internet routers may not process QoS. Not every device in the network needs QoS marking, such as infrastructure services like DHCP and DNS. QoS marking should also not be performed on the core router in the network; a good rule of thumb is don’t implement anything on the core router that could slow it down. The act of QoS marking could slow the core router down; already marked packets are fine.

answerChoices.Text: Closest to the source of the traffic
On every device in the network
On the core router in the network

questionText: Which is a correct statement about device trust boundary for QoS?
explanation: A malicious user can mark all of their traffic as high priority. Therefore, the network administrator must establish a trust boundary. A common trust boundary device is the IP phone, but it is any device that the network administrator controls. If the switch is set as a trust boundary, a malicious user could plug in and start marking their packets with a higher than normal QoS. Routers are not the only devices that create trust boundaries, and IP phones are not the only devices that can become trust boundaries.

answerChoices.Text: The trust boundary should always be an asset IT controls.
The switch should always be set as the trust boundary.
Only routers can create trust boundaries.
Only IP phones can become trust boundaries.

questionText: Which network is part of the summary route of 172.16.32.0/21?
explanation: The summary route of 172.16.32.0/21 contains 172.16.38.0/24 as a valid network route. The /21 CIDR mask defines networks in multiples of 8 in the third octet of the network address. Therefore, the next summary network address is 172.16.40.0/21. All of the other options are incorrect.

questionText: Which classification of IP address does 225.34.5.4 belong to?
explanation: The IP address 225.34.5.4 is a multicast IP address. Multicast IP addresses are defined as Class D addresses in the range 224.0.0.1 to 239.255.255.254. Class A defines any address with the first octet of 0 to 127. Class B defines any address with the first octet of 128 to 191. Class C defines any address with the first octet of 192 to 223.

questionText: What is the process of stateful DHCPv6 for IPv6?
explanation: Stateful DHCPv6 uses a process similar to DORA for IPv4. However, IPv6 uses multicast in lieu of broadcasts via the DHCPv6 Solicit multicast address. The Discover, Offer, Request, and Acknowledge (DORA) process only happens with IPv4 via broadcasts. Neighbor Solicitation (NS) and Neighbor Advertisement (NA) messages are used with the Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP). Router Solicitation (RS) and Router Advertisement (RA) messages are used with Stateless Autoconfiguration (SLAAC).

questionText: When SLAAC is performed on an IPv6 host, which process happens first?
explanation: Before a host can communicate via an RS packet, it first needs a valid IP address. The first address is a link-local address so that it can send an RS packet and receive an RA packet. The client performs Duplicate Address Detection (DAD) on the link-local address. Then a Router Solicitation (RS) message is sent from the client. A Router Advertisement (RA) message is sent from the router to the client with the network ID. The host portion is then configured and DAD is checked again to make sure that the host does not have a duplicate IP address.

answerChoices.Text: A Router Solicitation message is sent from the client.
A Router Advertisement message is sent from the router.
A link-local address is auto-configured on the client.
DAD is performed on the IPv6 address.

questionText: In IPv6, the solicited-node multicast message is used for what?
explanation: In IPv6, the solicited-node multicast message is used for resolution of the MAC address for an IPv6 address. The first 104 bits of the 128-bit IPv6 address is ff02::1:ff, and the last 24 bits comprise the last 24 bits of the IPv6 address that needs to be resolved. The solicited-node multicast message is also used for Duplicate Address Detection (DAD). All of the other options are incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: Resolution of the MAC address for an IPv6 address

questionText: When you configure a WLAN, what is the default QoS configured for the WLAN?
explanation: When you configure a WLAN and use the default QoS settings, the effective QoS is silver. Gold is used for video application on a wireless network. Bronze is the lowest level of traffic for unimportant traffic. Platinum is the highest level of traffic, and it is usually reserved for voice traffic over wireless.

questionText: In the following figure, why do the first and third ARP entries have a dash for their age?
explanation: The entries with the dash in the Age column represent the physical interfaces of the router. If the entries were configured statically, their type would reflect a status of static. Entries that have just been added to the ARP table will have an initial timer set. All entries in the ARP table will be displayed with their remaining time in seconds. Therefore, any entry with less than a minute left before it expires will be under 60 seconds.

answerChoices.Text: The entries are static ARP entries.
The entries have just been added to the ARP table.
The entries belong to the physical interfaces of the router.
The entries have less than 1 minute before they expire.

questionText: You see a number of IPv6 packets on your network with a destination address of ff02::a. What can be concluded about what is running on your network?
explanation: The multicast address of ff02::a is the multicast address for IPv6 EIGRP updates. Updates for routers participating in IPv6 EIGRP will be multicast to the IPv6 address of ff02::a. Routing Information Protocol Next Generation (RIPng) uses a multicast address of ff06::9. Open Shortest Path First version 3 (OSPFv3) uses multicast addresses of ff05::5 and ff05::6. Stateless Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) uses the link-local address that starts with fe80.

answerChoices.Text: Routing Information Protocol Next Generation (RIPng) is running on the network.
Open Shortest Path First version 3 (OSPFv3) is running on the network.
Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) for IPv6 is running on the network.
Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC) is running on the network.

questionText: Which is an disadvantage of using NAT?
explanation: Network Address Translation (NAT) creates packet switching path delay. This is because each address traveling through the NAT process requires lookup time for the translation. NAT does not introduce security weaknesses; it can actually be used to strengthen security, since private IP addresses are masqueraded behind a public IP address. NAT is often used so that address renumbering is not required when two networks are merged together with identical IP addressing. NAT does not increase bandwidth utilization at all.

questionText: Which command would you configure on the private network interface for NAT?
explanation: The command to configure the private side of the network interface for NAT is ip nat inside. This command is configured on the interface in which you want to define it as the “inside” of your network. The configuration of the command ip nat outside is incorrect. The commands ip nat inside gi0/0 and ip nat private are incorrect.

questionText: Why is time synchronization important for routers and switches?
explanation: Time synchronization is important for logging accuracy. Serial communication frame alignment is timed via clocking and packet queues are timed by how fast they can respond. The serialized communication for frame alignment comes from the DCE side of the link, which provides clocking signals. Time synchronization has no effect on quality of service queuing or the delivery of packets via timed queues.

answerChoices.Text: It is important for serialized communication frame alignment.
It is important for quality of service queuing.
It is important for logging accuracy.
It helps delivery of packets via timed queues.

questionText: Which protocol and port number does DNS use for direct queries?
explanation: Domain Name Services (DNS) direct queries are performed over the UDP protocol to port 53. The queries do not require the TCP setup and teardown because the queries are simple request and reply messages, so UDP is used for direct queries. TCP port 53 is used for DNS zone transfers between DNS servers. UDP port 55 is not used for any popular protocols. UDP port 68 is used with the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP).

questionText: Which version of SNMP supports the Inform SNMP message?
explanation: The introduction of SNMP version 2c added the Inform and Get-bulk messages for SNMP. SNMP version 1 was the first release of SNMP, and it did not support Inform and Get-bulk messages. SNMP version 2 was promptly replaced with SNMP version 2c; therefore, it is an invalid answer. SNMP version 3 introduced many new features such as security and encryption, to name a few.

questionText: Which command will configure all event logs to be sent to a syslog server?
explanation: The command logging host 192.168.1.6 will configure all logs to be sent to the syslog server 192.168.1.6. The commands logging server 192.168.1.6, logging 192.168.1.6, and syslog server 192.168.1.6 are incorrect.

questionText: Which command will allow you to verify the IP addresses assigned to a router’s interface?
explanation: The command show ip interface will display the IP addresses configured on the router’s interfaces. It will detail which are static and which have been allocated through DHCP. The command show ip dhcp bindings is incorrect because it will show the internal table for the local DHCP server. The commands show ip lease and show ip dhcp lease are incorrect.

questionText: Where should QoS marking be performed?
explanation: QoS marking should always be performed closest to the source of the traffic. All switches and routers in the network should be configured to properly prioritize markings of traffic in queues. If it is performed closest to the Internet router, you may not get any effectiveness from the configuration because Internet routers may not process QoS. Not every device in the network needs QoS marking, such as infrastructure services like DHCP and DNS. QoS marking should also not be performed on the core router in the network; a good rule of thumb is don’t implement anything on the core router that could slow it down. The act of QoS marking could slow the core router down; already marked packets are fine.

answerChoices.Text: Closest to the source of the traffic
On every device in the network
On the core router in the network

questionText: Which is a correct statement about device trust boundary for QoS?
explanation: A malicious user can mark all of their traffic as high priority. Therefore, the network administrator must establish a trust boundary. A common trust boundary device is the IP phone, but it is any device that the network administrator controls. If the switch is set as a trust boundary, a malicious user could plug in and start marking their packets with a higher than normal QoS. Routers are not the only devices that create trust boundaries, and IP phones are not the only devices that can become trust boundaries.

answerChoices.Text: The trust boundary should always be an asset IT controls.
The switch should always be set as the trust boundary.
Only routers can create trust boundaries.
Only IP phones can become trust boundaries.

questionText: Considering the differences between NAT and PAT, which is the most accurate description?
explanation: Both NAT and PAT can support multiple protocols for each of their translations. PAT translates multiple inside local addresses into a single global address. PAT is also used with pools when there are more inside devices than addresses in the pool and the keyword overload has been used in the configuration.NAT is a one-to-one translation of IP to IP.

answerChoices.Text: NAT allows for multiple protocols across a single IP address.
NAT translates many IP addresses into a few or even one IP address.
PAT allows for multiple protocols across multiple IP addresses.
PAT translates many IP addresses into a few or even one IP address.

questionText: A colleague asked you to help troubleshoot a problem with their NAT/PAT configuration on router R1. NAT/PAT should translate packets sent by hosts in subnet 10.1.2.0/24 that are destined for the Internet. All translations should use R1's IP address in network 192.0.2.0 from the Internet link. (Consider network 192.0.2.0 to be a public IP network for this question.) Which answer identifies the action required to fix the configuration error?
explanation:
For the correct answer, as configured, ACL 1 matches only the address 10.1.2.2. The syntax shown in a standard ACL implies matching a host (a single IP address). The correct command, which matches all IP address in the subnet, is access-list 1 permit 10.1.2.0 0.0.0.255.

	For the incorrect answers, the ip nat inside command has no issues, and the ip nat inside and ip nat outside reside on the correct R1 interfaces. Moving the configuration to router R2 would not work because R2 has no public IP addresses to use, and the configuration, if moved as is, still has the configuration issue with access-list 1.

answerChoices.Text: Move this configuration to router R2 instead of router R1.
Swap the interfaces on which the ip nat inside and ip nat outside command are configured.

questionText: Your company has configured all the internal IP addressing using private IP addresses. You then realize that some users will also want Internet access. What is the practical approach to solving this problem?
explanation: Using NAT at a perimeter router, and converting the private source addresses to global addresses before sending those packets into the public networks, would allow the internal users to access Internet resources.Using NAT to make the entire Internet appear as an inside local private address space is not reasonable. Assigning permanent static public IPs to individual hosts or dual homing those hosts just for Internet access is also not practical.

answerChoices.Text: Assign the internal hosts that need to access the Internet static public IP addresses on their workstations
Use a second network adapter on their workstation for the public access
Use NAT to make the Internet appear as local IP addresses, which are reachable by internal users
Configure translation to make the Internet believe the users have public addresses

questionText: You are the administrator of the network pictured in the figure. The exhibit shows the configuration for router A that a colleague has proposed. The goal of the configuration is to use PAT, translating addresses for hosts on router A's LAN, with a single global IP address from the serial 0 interface. Which of the following answers best describes what you must change for your colleague's configuration to correctly implement PAT?
explanation:
The configuration does have an issue (a fact that rules out one answer as incorrect). The correct answer lists the reason: the ip nat inside and ip nat outside commands were on incorrect interfaces.

	As for the other incorrect answers, they suggest changing the ip nat inside source command or the ACL used by NAT. Both are correct as is.

answerChoices.Text: Change the ip nat inside source command.
Reverse the location of the ip nat inside and ip nat outside commands.
The configuration works fine as is.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a voice network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a voice network, one-way delay is kept below 150 ms, jitter is kept below 30 ms, and loss is kept under 1%.

questionText: Which DSCP value is suggested to be used for packets that need low latency, low jitter, and low loss?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Expedited Forwarding (EF) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) value for use on traffic that requires low latency, low jitter, and low loss.

questionText: Which options are not one of the manageable QoS characteristics of network traffic?
explanation: There are four QoS characteristics of network traffic: bandwidth, delay, jitter, and loss.

questionText: Which QoS feature is typically used outbound to an ISP to reduce the amount of traffic that is dropped by exceeding the purchased rate?
explanation: Often a connection to an Internet service provider (ISP) is physically connected with a technology that exceeds the purchased rate. To control the amount of traffic that is allowed onto their network, ISPs limit the rate that traffic is allowed to flow into the network. This is done with traffic policers; to limit the amount of traffic that could potentially be dropped by the ISP’s policer, an enterprise could choose to shape the traffic going out of their network and to the ISP.

questionText: What is the name of the IPv6 packet field that is used for marking DSCP values?
explanation: The IPv6 header includes the Traffic Class field that is used for marking traffic with Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) values.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a video network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a video network, one-way delay is kept below 400 ms (200 to 400 ms), jitter is kept below 50 ms (preferably lower than 30 ms), and loss is kept under 1%.

questionText: Which QoS feature is typically used inbound to a network to limit the amount of traffic that is allowed to flow in?
explanation: Typically traffic policers are used to control the flow of traffic coming into a network from a separate network (e.g., another company or customer). They do this by setting a limit to the amount of traffic that is allowed to be sent. There are a variety of ways that this rate can be configured, but generally a committed information rate (CIR) is used as an average measurement of allowed rate with an ability to allow for traffic spikes over short amounts of time.

questionText: What is the field that is used on modern systems that allows an IP packet to be marked with a specific QoS value?
explanation: On modern networks, the IP Type of Service field is split into two subfields: the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) and the Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) field; of these, the DSCP is primarily used for marking traffic with a specific QoS value.

questionText: __________ means that the QoS tool changes one or more header fields, setting a value in the header.
explanation: Marking means that the QoS tool changes one or more header fields, setting a value in the header.

questionText: Which congestion management solution was designed specifically for voice and video that has specialized low delay, jitter, and loss requirements?
explanation: The Low Latency Queuing (LLQ) congestion management solution was designed specifically for traffic that has specific low delay, jitter, and loss requirements. LLQ provides preferential treatment for this traffic over other class-based queuing methods so that regardless of the current congestion conditions the traffic is forwarded.

questionText: The term _________ refers to the process of matching the fields in a message to make a choice to take some QoS action.
explanation: The term classification refers to the process of matching the fields in a message to make a choice to take some QoS action.

questionText: What is the name of the Cisco feature that allows for the identification of protocols that are traditionally hard to classify because of their operation?
explanation: Cisco’s Network Based Application Recognition (NBAR) and its successor NBAR2 allow for engineers to match protocols that have been traditionally very hard to classify because of their operation; an example includes the use of various dynamic ports.

questionText: Which QoS options are recommended by Cisco when designing for a voice network?
explanation: Cisco recommends that when designing for a voice network, one-way delay is kept below 150 ms, jitter is kept below 30 ms, and loss is kept under 1%.
comments: 12/13 - good as-is, 11/27 - query to Au, 5/12 - Good as-is, 5/9 - query to Au

questionText: Which DSCP marking group was created to be backward compatible with Internet Protocol Precedence (IPP) values?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Class Selector (CS) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) as a set of values  designed to be backward compatible with Internet Protocol Precedence (IPP) numbering. IPP was used on networks before DSCPs were defined.

questionText: Which DSCP Assured Forwarding value provides the worst drop and worst queue performance?
explanation: DiffServ defines the Assured Forwarding (AF) Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) as a set of values that are used with each other. Traffic is separated into four different classes and three different drop priorities, resulting in a grid of 12 different AF values that are marked based on the intended use of the traffic. The AF13 marking results in traffic having the lowest queue priority and the highest drop probability.
comments: 4/12 - ok as-is, " You’d think AF11 would be worst and worst, respectively, particularly as it’s decimal value is the lowest number, but they didn’t do it that way. AF13 is indeed worst of all 12 AF values. See Figure 11-11 in Volume 2. EG, both AF11 and AF13 has the worst queuing preference. But AF11 is the best preference for drop, while AF13 is the worst, because AF13 has a higher percentage chance of being dropped compared to AFx1."   4/11 - query to Au

questionText: A router uses the low latency queuing (LLQ) feature on its WAN interface, with all voice packets using the priority queue and three data classes using non-priority queues. The WAN link becomes congested with both voice and data traffic. How does the router service the queues?
explanation:
Routers that use Low Latency Queuing (LLQ) always schedule the priority queue if packets exist in the queue. As a result, the other queues might suffer queue starvation when the link has too much load. To combat that issue, the LLQ feature also limits the amount of traffic that can be sent through the priority queue, discarding any excess traffic using a policing function, thereby leaving enough bandwidth for the non-priority queues.

	In this specific question, for the correct answers, the LLQ feature schedules the queue with priority scheduling for the priority queue, but with limits as implemented by policing. It also schedules the other queues in a round-robin fashion.

answerChoices.Text: Priority scheduling with no limits for voice
Priority scheduling with limits (policing) for voice
Round robin scheduling for the three data queues
Round robin scheduling for all four queues

questionText: NAT translates a private address 192.168.1.1 to a public IP address 12.150.146.100. How would 192.168.1.1 be described?
explanation: The term inside refers to a host inside the Enterprise network, which often uses a private (RFC 1918) address inside the Enterprise. The term local refers to an address used for that host in the local, or Enterprise, network.

questionText: The internetworks created by Enterprises A and B both connect to the Internet, allowing all users to connect to hosts in the Internet and hosts in the other Enterprise. Enterprise C is totally isolated, not connecting to the Internet or to other companies. Which of the following are true about the use of public and private IP addresses in this scenario?
explanation: Private IP networks were originally intended for use inside  organizations that had no reason to connect to the Internet or to other  organizations. However, the looming IPv4 address shortage in the early  1990s required some solutions, one of which is NAT/PAT. PAT allows  organizations to use a small number of public IP addresses, assigning  private IP addresses to each individual host, with a device translating  addresses in packets sent to and from the Internet. This allows two  organizations to use the same IP address ranges and still be able to  communicate through the Internet.

answerChoices.Text: Enterprises A and B must assign public IP addresses to all hosts in their respective internetworks
Enterprises A and B can both use private IP networks, but they cannot use the same private network
Enterprise C can use any private network
Enterprises A and B can both use private network 10.0.0.0 as long as they also use NAT or PAT

questionText: Which two commands could be used to check if DNS name resolution is working properly on a Windows PC? (Choose two.)
explanation:
The ping command tests the connection between two hosts. When ping uses a host domain name to test the connection, the resolver on the PC will first perform the name resolution to query the DNS server for the IP address of the host. If the ping command is unable to resolve the domain name to an IP address, an error will result.
Nslookup is a tool for testing and troubleshooting DNS servers.

questionText: Only employees connected to IPv6 interfaces are having difficulty connecting to remote networks. The analyst wants to verify that IPv6 routing has been enabled. What is the best command to use to accomplish the task?
explanation: The 'show running-config' command displays the current configuration of the device, including whether IPv6 routing is enabled. The other commands are not directly related to verifying IPv6 routing status.

questionText: Which command is used to manually query a DNS server to resolve a specific host name?
explanation: The nslookup command was created to allow a user to manually query a DNS server to resolve a given host name. The ipconfig /displaydns command only displays previously resolved DNS entries. The tracert command was created to examine the path that packets take as they cross a network and can resolve a hostname by automatically querying a DNS server. The net command is used to manage network computers, servers, printers, and network drives.

questionText:
Network information:
* local router LAN interface: 172.19.29.254 / fe80:65ab:dcc1::10
* local router WAN interface: 198.133.219.33 / 2001:db8:FACE:39::10
* remote server: 192.135.250.103
What task might a user be trying to accomplish by using the ping 2001:db8:FACE:39::10 command?
explanation: The IP address 2001:db8:FACE:39::10 is configured on the local router's WAN interface, which connects to the internet. Therefore, pinging this address verifies connectivity to the internet from the local router's perspective.

answerChoices.Text: verifying that there is connectivity within the local network
creating a network performance benchmark to a server on the company intranet
determining the path to reach the remote server
verifying that there is connectivity to the internet

questionText:
In layer 3 switch D2 in the figure, an engineer needs to disable CDP and LLDP on the G1/0/2 interface but enable them both on all the other interfaces. The output below lists all non-default configuration commands for CDP and LLDP. Which answer lists the briefest configuration that would meet the goals if pasting the configuration into global configuration mode? Reject any answers IOS would reject when pasting the commands into configuration mode. 


lldp run
interface G1/0/2
  no lldp receive
explanation:
You can achieve the stated goal by enabling CDP and LLDP by default while configuring the interface subcommands that disable CDP and LLDP on a particular interface, in this case, G1/0/1.

IOS defaults to use the cdp run and no lldp run global commands, enabling CDP and disabling LLDP globally. That means the interfaces use CDP unless an interface subcommand disables it (no cdp enable.) Conversely, with an LLDP global default of disabled, interfaces do not use LLDP unless an interface subcommand enables it (lldp transmit and lldp receive.)
However, the supplied configuration overrides the LLDP default, enabling LLDP globally with the lldp run global command. With those facts in mind, per the initial configuration, the question begins with the following:


	Both CDP and LLDP globally enabled
	LLDP partially disabled on G1/0/2
	CDP is fully functioning, and LLDP is partially functioning on G1/0/2


To disable CDP on the interface, use the no cdp enable interface subcommand, as seen in the correct answer. To disable LLDP on the interface, you need both the no lldp receive and no lldp transmit subcommands. The configuration already includes the first, so the correct answer adds the second of those commands.

Two incorrect answers list a command IOS will reject: no lldp enable. While IOS uses the no cdp enable interface subcommand to disable CDP on an interface, IOS does not support a no lldp enable interface subcommand. Those answers would not disable LLDP and would also show a command error when pasting the configuration.

Finally, consider the incorrect answer that begins with cdp run but which also has a no lldp transmit command. This answer makes the functions work as intended. However, it requires one additional command compared to the correct answer. The question asked for the briefest configuration that meets the goals, making this answer incorrect.

answerChoices.Text:
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp transmit

interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp enable

cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp enable

cdp run
interface GigabitEthernet1/0/2
  no cdp enable
  no lldp transmit

questionText: Given network 172.18.109.0, which subnet mask would be used if 6 host bits were available?
explanation:
With an IPv4 network, the subnet mask is determined by the hosts bits that are required:
11 host bits required – 255.255.248.0
10 host bits required – 255.255.252.0
9 host bits required – 255.255.254.0
8 host bits required – 255.255.255.0
7 host bits required – 255.255.255.128
6 host bits required – 255.255.255.192
5 host bits required – 255.255.255.224
4 host bits required – 255.255.255.240
3 host bits required – 255.255.255.248
2 host bits required – 255.255.255.252

questionText: Which type of IPv4 address is 172.16.4.254 in the network 172.16.4.0/23?
explanation: Given the network 172.16.4.0/23, the subnet mask is 255.255.254.0. The range of usable IP addresses for this network is from 172.16.4.1 to 172.16.5.254. Since 172.16.4.254 falls within this range, it is a valid public unicast address.

questionText: What does the IP address 192.168.1.15/29 represent?
explanation: A broadcast address is the last address of any given network. This address cannot be assigned to a host, and it is used to communicate with all hosts on that network. For a /29 subnet, there are 8 addresses in each subnet. If 192.168.1.15 is the last address in its /29 subnet, it would be the broadcast address.

questionText: Why is NAT not needed in IPv6?
explanation: The large number of public IPv6 addresses eliminates the need for NAT. Sites from the largest enterprises to single households can get public IPv6 network addresses. This avoids some of the NAT-induced application problems that are experienced by applications that require end-to-end connectivity.

answerChoices.Text: Because IPv6 has integrated security, there is no need to hide the IPv6 addresses of internal networks.
The problems that are induced by NAT applications are solved because the IPv6 header improves packet handling by intermediate routers.
The end-to-end connectivity problems that are caused by NAT are solved because the number of routes increases with the number of nodes that are connected to the Internet.
Any host or user can get a public IPv6 network address because the number of available IPv6 addresses is extremely large.

questionText: Which term describes a field in the IPv4 packet header that contains a unicast, multicast, or broadcast address?
explanation: The Destination IPv4 Address field in the IPv4 packet header contains the IP address of the destination host. This address can be a unicast, multicast, or broadcast address.

questionText: Which is the compressed format of the IPv6 address fe80:0000:0000:0000:0220:0b3f:f0e0:0029?
explanation: To compress an IPv6 address: 1. Remove leading zeros from each hextet (e.g., 0000 becomes 0, 0220 becomes 220). 2. Compress one or more consecutive hextets of '0's with a double colon (::). In this case, fe80:0000:0000:0000:0220:0b3f:f0e0:0029 becomes fe80::220:b3f:f0e0:29.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. A user issues the command netstat –r on a workstation. Which IPv6 address is one of the link-local addresses of the workstation?
explanation: In the IPv6 address scheme, the network of fe80::/10 is reserved for link-local addresses. The address fe80::/64 is a network address that indicates, in this workstation, fe80::/64 is actually used for link-local addresses. Thus the address fe80::30d0:115:3f57:fe4c/128 is a valid IPv6 link-local address.

questionText: What type of IPv6 address is represented by ::1/128?
explanation: The IPv6 address ::1/128 is the loopback address. It is used to test the TCP/IP stack on the local host.

questionText: In the figure, router R1 enables an ACL inbound on its G0/0/0 interface. Hosts A and B need to lease IP addresses from DHCP server S1. Router R1 provides the IP helper feature with the ip helper-address 172.16.2.1 subcommand on its G0/0/0 interface. Which answers list an ACE that, if part of the ACL, would match DHCP messages between the server and clients?
explanation:
The DHCP messages per this question use:


	UDP
	Source address 0.0.0.0 (client address before leasing an address)
	Destination IP address 255.255.255.255 (destination used by clients because they do not know the DHCP server’s address.)
	Destination port 67 (bootps)


In this scenario, the ACL inbound on R1’s G0/0/0 interface processes the DHCP messages before the IP helper function on R1 changes the IP addresses. As a result, at this point, the router must match the special-purpose source and destination addresses 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255.255, respectively.

Of the two answers that use the ip protocol keyword, both attempt to match address 172.16.2.1. The DHCP messages do not use that address as the source or destination address, making those answers incorrect.
